pros:
I worked with an amazing team in a great department. Health benefits were decent.

Depending on what departments you're in, there are some amazing people doing great things.
cons:
You will only move ahead in your career if you are the favorite of one of the VPs.

HR will deny promotions or requests to have your title changed to something more relevant to what you actually do (even if you aren’t asking for more money) because you “don’t have enough experience” - even if you’ve shown years of documented relevant work that exactly correlated to what you’re requesting. “Other duties as assigned,” amiright? HR doesn’t seem to value degrees/credentials from TAMIU, which is alarming. 

 The pay is absolutely not competitive, and they will replace you with someone less qualified that they can pay less money to in a heartbeat. 

It’s insulting how undervalued staff is. 

During COVID, they withheld merit pay, citing concerns about enrollment. A year and serious hard work across the university later, enrollment was up - and they repaid those efforts with mere pennies. It was an insult. 

It’s no wonder so many people are leaving.

pros: University is good but Laredo may not be everyone's cup of tea.

review_title: Great atmosphere with politics around every corner
pros: Located in a small town community, working at TAMIU will give you an opportunity to meet, collaborate, and understand many different cultures and personalities from across the globe.
cons: Depending on your career field, the hierarchy for progressing your career is mostly locked and out of reach. Many false prospects of upward career movement exist and present themselves. However, the bureaucracy of the institution tends to stifle and even provoke certain departments and employees across campus. After some time, only a small percentage of employees across campus have an opportunity to progress themselves.

job_title: Technical Assistant I in College Station, TX
pros: It was a good experience because I worked with people whom I already knew from my time as a graduate assistant.
cons: I did not get paid much and there were no benefits or health insurance. However, that was made clear to me before I accepted the position.

pros: Good location that provides needed higher educational opportunities to under served residents
cons: It's gotten caught up in a numbers game to graduate people out of professional programs that do not meet standards of competency.

pros: Student body is predominantly 1st-gen college, low income. This university is positioned to be really transformative in this community.
cons: The administration is in a somewhat adolescent phase- power is brokered with social connections. Neither quality nor quantity of work is valued by upper level admins- complicity and acquiescence are what they want in employees. Knowledge is traded as a commodity, not shared as an asset. When the administration turns over, the university is likely to bloom.

pros: It is a job that pays money if you are related to someone working there.  If you are related to the president even better.
cons: The morale is low, people in positions of power micromanage.  President will restructure to clean house and supervisors typically not qualified for their positions. They greatly prefer to employ TAMIU alumni and would rather give the position to a someone related to the school over a competent and experienced applicant. Don't apply to recruitment unless you are good looking (there is a standard). Upper administration bullies lower ranks. Don't complain or you will place a target on your back. The outcome will be against you no matter the evidence or proof. Absolute intellectual incest.

- Innovative thinking could be constrained by in-house policies
